articles.headline: Paul Manafort, Trump’s Former Campaign Chairman, Guilty of 8 Counts
articles.snippet: The verdict was a victory for the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, whose inquiry has drawn withering criticism from President Trump.
articles.abstract: The verdict was a victory for the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, whose inquiry has drawn withering criticism from President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, was convicted on Tuesday in his financial fraud trial, bringing a dramatic end to a politically charged case that riveted the capital.

articles.headline: A Plan to Unlock Billions of Barrels of Oil From Utah’s Sands
articles.snippet: Backers say their method will avoid the environmental toll incurred in Canada’s oil sands — some others aren’t so sure — and will yield profits at half the current price of crude.
articles.abstract: Backers say their method will avoid the environmental toll incurred in Canada’s oil sands — some others aren’t so sure — and will yield profits at half the current price of crude.
articles.lead_paragraph: VERNAL, Utah — Utah is a yawn amid the drilling frenzy that has upended the energy picture in recent years. It accounts for just one of every 100 barrels of oil produced nationwide.

articles.headline: Facebook Identifies New Influence Operations Spanning Globe
articles.snippet: The social network removed hundreds of fake accounts and pages targeting people in different countries and regions that originated in Iran and Russia.
articles.abstract: The social network removed hundreds of fake accounts and pages targeting people in different countries and regions that originated in Iran and Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook said on Tuesday that it had identified multiple new  influence campaigns that were aimed at misleading people around the world, with the company finding and removing 652 fake accounts, pages and groups that were trying to sow misinformation.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: A One-Two Punch Puts Trump Back on His Heels
articles.snippet: The conviction of Paul Manafort and guilty plea by Michael D. Cohen could open fissures among Republicans on Capitol Hill and expose President Trump to the possibility of impeachment.
articles.abstract: The conviction of Paul Manafort and guilty plea by Michael D. Cohen could open fissures among Republicans on Capitol Hill and expose President Trump to the possibility of impeachment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In two courtrooms 200 miles apart on Tuesday, President Trump’s almost daily attempts to dismiss the criminal investigations that have engulfed his White House all but collapsed.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler, Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Bull Market Hits a Milestone: 3,453 Days. Most Americans Aren’t at the Party.
articles.snippet: By one measure, stocks crossed a major threshold on Wednesday. But the financial gains of the nearly decade-long run have been concentrated among the already wealthy.
articles.abstract: By one measure, stocks crossed a major threshold on Wednesday. But the financial gains of the nearly decade-long run have been concentrated among the already wealthy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The party has been going for nearly a decade. But a lot of Americans haven’t been celebrating.

articles.headline: Google Tried to Change China. China May End Up Changing Google.
articles.snippet: Google once held itself up as proudly nonconformist. A decision to abide by Chinese censors would mark a new era for the company — one of conventionality.
articles.abstract: Google once held itself up as proudly nonconformist. A decision to abide by Chinese censors would mark a new era for the company — one of conventionality.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since its founding 20 years ago in a Silicon Valley garage, Google has proudly and often ostentatiously held itself up as the architect of a new model for corporate virtue.

articles.headline: Republicans Urge Embattled Incumbents to Speak Out on Trump
articles.snippet: Fearing more shoes will drop, Republican leaders have begun urging some incumbents to speak out on President Trump’s misdeeds, while Democrats stress a “culture of corruption.”
articles.abstract: Fearing more shoes will drop, Republican leaders have begun urging some incumbents to speak out on President Trump’s misdeeds, while Democrats stress a “culture of corruption.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior Republican Party leaders began urging their most imperiled incumbents on Wednesday to speak out about the wrongdoing surrounding President Trump, with Representative Tom Cole, a former House Republican campaign chairman, warning, “Where there’s smoke, and there’s a lot of smoke, there may well be fire.”
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: China’s Consumption Downgrade: Skip Avocados, Cocktails and Kids
articles.snippet: Amid an economic slowdown and the trade war with the U.S., many Chinese consumers are cutting back. That could be bad news for the global economy.
articles.abstract: Amid an economic slowdown and the trade war with the U.S., many Chinese consumers are cutting back. That could be bad news for the global economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chen Siqi doesn’t eat out so much anymore. Li Keli cut down on travel and takes her son to a public playground instead. Wang Jiazhi stopped dating.

articles.headline: Trump Praises Manafort, Saying ‘Unlike Michael Cohen’ He ‘Refused to Break’
articles.snippet: The president attacked Mr. Cohen as a bad lawyer and said that he had “such respect for a brave man,” a reference to Paul Manafort, who was convicted of tax and bank fraud.
articles.abstract: The president attacked Mr. Cohen as a bad lawyer and said that he had “such respect for a brave man,” a reference to Paul Manafort, who was convicted of tax and bank fraud.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Wednesday praised his just-convicted former campaign chairman for refusing to “break” and cooperate with federal prosecutors investigating Russia’s interference in the 2016 election, expressing appreciation for the personal loyalty of a felon found guilty of defrauding the United States government.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Eileen Sullivan
